ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about the universe and a basic overview of the science and mathematics behind it, as well as a historical overview of cosmological discoveries.
An overview of concepts and tools in studying cosmology.

I really got a solid grasp as to what are universe is made up of and how it interacts with itself. In addition I really got to nail down more fundamental physics principles I had not gotten the chance to before.

I developed basic knowledge of the history and structure of the universe, and some understanding of how to do basic calculations of involving the mass of stars and black holes and the densities of different elements in the universe.
A much greater understanding of the universe, including the materials and bodies that comprise it and the laws that govern it.
Knowledge of basic cosmology, black holes, general relativity and the Friedmann equations

I learned about cosmology, as the course's title suggests! I acquired a solid foundation in the physics and history of the universe. I also learned about applying math and intuition to problems about stars, galaxies, and matter.
A lot of insight about the universe and its nature, as well as a really cool breakdown of dark matter and universal expansion.
Knowledge of celestial objects, history of the Universe, properties such as gravity.
I learned a lot of new information about space.
I learned all about the universe's history and fate, star lifecycles, some relativity, overall principles of cosmology and science. It was great.

We covered a wide range of different topics in this course, from star formation to general and special relativity. I left this course with a solid conceptual foundation of the composition and origins of the Universe, as well as the laws of physics which govern it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Interesting subject material, Professor Natarajan clearly has a lot of knowledge to share, open-ended final projects, good pacing of assignments. Weaknesses: First half of the course covered fairly easy material and went kinda slowly while the second half covered much more complex topics, and some important but challenging topics were seemingly rushed (and then showed up on exams).

Strength is open note exams very fair, and no final exam
Weakness is final project length

I think the material is genuinely interesting. It's really cool to engage with the fundamental truths of our universe and understand what's going on in the Cosmos. I liked being able to understand, if only on a basic level, what rules govern our universe and how our understanding of the universe changes over time. One improvement I would suggest is a more engaging format than reading/working off of a slideshow. I found myself disengaged often in class because the subject matter was so broad and it felt like such a mass of information coming at me that I would just wait until after the lecture to try to actually process the lectures. Writing on the board or simply talking might be a more engaging method of information delivery than working off of a pre-made slideshow.

Strengths: really interesting material presented in an understandable way by a brilliant, engaging professor
weakness: I really enjoyed the final project and wish we had a similar mid-semester project, or possibly a research project about a scientist of our choice.
Great course overall

I found the lectures engaging, and the problem sets were interesting. I appreciated the emphasis on the ideas underlying the quantitative skills we were learning. I sometimes wished for more feedback on assignments.
Lectures were well-organized, homework and tests were spread out well throughout the semester.

I think the strengths of the course is that if you are interested in the subject manner but don't have a strong background in math or physics, it is packaged in a way that makes the math easy. Another strength of the course is the final project. It is nice to have flexibility in what I choose to research or do. It is also really interesting hearing other student's projects. I think this course has a few weaknesses. It starts really slow but gets more interesting as the class goes along. Its a small lecture but it would definitely be helpful to have discussion sections as sometimes it can be really hard to understand the material conceptually.

This course was amazing, likely the best class I've taken. The problemsets were meaningful and interesting, the textbook was great, and the lectures were absolutely wonderful. So engaging, so interesting. I recommend this class more than any other class I've taken.

I liked how this course focused on the actual techniques and methods astronomers used to discover the facts we know about the Universe and included references to the history of scientific discoveries. Allusions in class to current open questions in cosmology and ongoing research to solve them were also fascinating.

I think this course suffers a bit from being too ambitious with the amount of information it attempts to convey. While I enjoyed receiving such a comprehensive survey of cosmology, trying to cover that many different topics meant that parts of the course inevitably felt rushed and not sufficiently explained in depth. While these sections of the course were never tested, that also meant I was less motivated to engage with and truly understand that material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is NOT a gut course, but it is a fairly easy course. You will have to study and you will have to work with the TF's, but it is not a hard class to do good in.

If you genuinely want an overview of cosmology. The workload was low but definitely required some effort. I felt lucky having already taken several advanced math classes at Yale, and I could imagine that someone with a weaker science or (especially) math background would have a harder time grasping some of the more technical concepts.
Yes easy science-credit, interesting class
Yes, brilliant professor. Reasonable workload. Interesting content.

I would recommend this course if you are someone who enjoys learning in general but does not love doing actual analysis. For me, this course would have been better if there was a greater focus on math, but you can decide whether this course would be right for you with a very simple question: do I want to learn the history of our understanding of the universe? The focus of lectures is much more on the history of our own understanding than the history of the universe itself.
I definitely would recommend this course to another student as it was intellectually engaging without needless work. I also think everyone should have at least a basic understanding of our universe.

Yes, as a somewhat introductory course, the course does a good job of balancing relaying new scientific concepts and keeping it grounded enough to where anyone with an interest in STEM would be able to understand.
Yea

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in cosmology or broad questions about the universe. It's not a gut, but it's also completely doable for anyone with solid mathematical intuition. I'm not sure I would recommend it, though, to someone who doesn't like tinkering with numbers.
Great primer for cosmological concepts, even if you do not plan on being an astronomy-related major.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in the subject manner. It is definitely hard if your interest in the subject manner is not at a high level.
Yes, absolutely. The workload was not bad and it was so incredibly interesting. It was wonderful!

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in astronomy or physics. I think it is especially well-suited to humanities majors like myself who are interested in physics but would rather engage with it on a conceptual rather than a mathematical level.
